title: Bank loyalty tax doubles to $6b since June
text:
The ACCC describes the higher rates as a loyalty tax and they are understood to be worth billions to the banks.

Lendi’s Mr Hyman said he was hopeful that the narrow terms of reference of the inquiry would deliver much needed transparency around mortgage pricing and stop banks from treating loyal customers poorly.

“If you are an optimist, these discrepancies will become a thing of the past,” Mr Hyman said.

Differential pricing of mortgages has emerged as a key weapon for the banks as they look to offset a range of headwinds including lower fee revenue, higher compliance costs and slimmer margins.

Analysis of the front to back book discount has typically assumed a margin of 41 basis points, the mid-point between the two discount rates established by the ACCC and the Productivity Commission.

While the figure moves around, a 79 basis point loyalty tax could mean as much as $6 billion to the big four banks, which last year made a profit of $27 billion.

Mr Hyman said the widening gap was evidence of fierce competition in the sector as the big four banks looked to defend their turf from well resourced challengers such as HSBC and Macquarie. ANZ, Westpac and NAB are scheduled to deliver full-year results over the next two weeks.

“It’s pretty widely understood the major profit pools of the big four are under pressure, particularly with the capital impositions and the major bank levy and so on. Maybe short term it plugs the gap but over the longer term, consumers will take matters into their own hands,” Mr Hyman said.

Advertisement

The RBA has cut rates three times since June as it looks to stimulate investment against a backdrop of sluggish growth. As the cash rate approaches zero, banks are increasingly unable to pass the full cuts through without damaging profitability.

The data has been collected from the online mortgage platform’s user base of owner-occupier borrowers paying principal and interest with a loan-to-valuation ratio of less than 80 per cent.

On Lendi’s data, a borrower with a $760,000 mortgage is being slugged with an additional $328 a month in repayments, or close to $4,000 a year. Mr Hyman said customers needed to be aware of the premium they were paying for loyalty to their bank.

“Customers need to be aware of their options because, quite frankly, many cannot afford to keep paying a loyalty premium in the current economic climate,” he said.

“It’s these cost pressures on everyday households which are helping fuel demand for loans from the newer digital lenders who are passing on rate cuts quickly and in full.”
description: The margin between what banks charge loyal customers and what they use to entice new business has soared since the RBA started cutting rates in June.
